Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploring the Feasibility of System Support for Managing Risk in Cloud Markets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cloud computing has become the foundation of our information-based economy, providing the computing power necessary for advances in transportation, energy, communication, healthcare, science, and entertainment. Early cloud platforms were simple, requiring users to choose from a small number of servers "on-demand" for a fixed per-hour price. However, modern cloud platforms are evolving into full-fledged markets that offer servers under a range of complex contracts that expose applications to different forms of risk, such as the risk of price increases, server revocations, or server shortages. By offering such contracts, cloud platforms can increase their infrastructure's utilization, revenue, and energy-efficiency, while cloud users can lower their costs by tailoring their contracts to match their applications' requirements. Unfortunately, given the complexity of cloud contracts and the relationship between risk, application correctness, and performance, developing risk-aware applications represents a significant challenge. To address the challenge, this project will explore the feasibility of system support for managing risk in cloud markets by adapting and extending concepts from economics and finance. A key goal of the project is to elevate risk management to a first-class systems design principle.

The project includes multiple broader impacts. By enabling better risk management, cloud platforms can significantly increase their utilization and energy-efficiency, while also lowering users' costs. The project will incorporate modules on cloud economics and managing risk in cloud platforms into undergraduate and graduate seminars, which will relate it to core concepts in operating systems, networking, and distributed systems. The researchers also plan to integrate cloud economics topics from the project into seminars on cloud computing for aspiring college students they regularly give. As part of the project's data management plan, the investigators will also collect, aggregate, and archive real-time market data from public cloud platforms and make it publicly available through a web-based data repository. Finally, the project will emphasize the recruitment of students from under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cloud computing platforms provide the computing infrastructure necessary to support our information-based economy.  Modern cloud platforms offer computing resources under a variety of different purchasing options or contracts, which differ in their cost, risk, performance, and availability. By selling computing resources under different contracts, cloud platforms can increase their infrastructure’s utilization, revenue, and energy-efficiency.  This project examined software system support for managing the risk and cost of different contracts in cloud platforms for different types of applications and workloads. In doing so, the project developed multiple techniques to reduce the cost of using cloud platforms.  Specifically, the project developed a new resource deflation technique that imposes less risk and overhead on interactive applications compared to spot/preemptible resources.  The project also developed techniques for optimally provisioning spot/preemptible resources offered by cloud platforms for mixed interactive and batch workloads based on their cost and probability of revocation.  Finally, the project developed and evaluated the concept of a waiting policy, which is the dual of a scheduling policy, to optimally provision reserved cloud resources for batch workloads. Collectively, these techniques are capable of both increasing cloud cost-efficiency and energy-efficiency, and reducing end-user costs for multiple types of workloads, e.g., batch, interactive, and mixed. 

We have incorporated principles from the project into two graduate courses, and an undergraduate course in systems design at our university. Ideas from the project served as inspiration for course projects, and undergraduate Honors theses. We also taught a module and guided tutorials on cloud computing for rising high school juniors as part of a summer program to introduce high school students to engineering topics. The project enabled multiple internships for students at companies that operate major cloud platforms, enabling them to apply ideas from the project in practice. A Ph.D. student that worked on the project accepted a full-time position on the infrastructure management team of a large-scale cloud provider.  We also publicly released code and data from the project, including job traces from a large shared batch cluster and price archives from a public cloud platform, to both enable reproducibility of our results and promote future research.
